bugs.title: CVE-2018-7995 kernel: Race condition in the store_int_with_restart() function in cpu/mcheck/mce.c

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2018-7995 kernel: Race condition in the store_int_with_restart() function in cpu/mcheck/mce.c

long_desc.thetext:
Race condition in the store_int_with_restart() function in arch/x86/kernel/cpu/mcheck/mce.c in the Linux kernel allows local users to cause a denial of service (panic) by leveraging root access to write to the check_interval file in a /sys/devices/system/machinecheck/machinecheck<cpu number> directory.

References:

https://lkml.org/lkml/2018/3/2/970

An upsteam patch:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=b3b7c4795ccab5be71f080774c45bbbcc75c2aaf

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1553918]
kernel-4.15.9-200.fc26 has been pushed to the Fedora 26 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.

Notes:

Since only root can write to the mentioned sysfs variables, the issue is not a security flaw.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

bugs.title: CVE-2018-8043 kernel: NULL pointer dereference in drivers/net/phy/mdio-bcm-unimac.c:unimac_mdio_probe() can lead to denial of service

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2018-8043 kernel: NULL pointer dereference in drivers/net/phy/mdio-bcm-unimac.c:unimac_mdio_probe() can lead to denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
The Linux kernel was found vulnerable to a NULL pointer dereference in the drivers/net/phy/mdio-bcm-unimac.c:unimac_mdio_probe() function caused by an unchecked return value from the platform_get_resource() function. A successful flaw exploitation can cause a system panic and a denial of service. This flaw is believed not to be an attacker triggerable as bad return value can be caused by hardware misconfiguration.

References:

https://marc.info/?l=kernel-janitors&m=151566944123938&w=2

An upstream fix:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=297a6961ffb8ff4dc66c9fbf53b924bd1dda05d5

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1554200]
kernel-4.15.9-200.fc26 has been pushed to the Fedora 26 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.

comments.text: This update has been submitted for testing by labbott.

wfm:
desktop 16GB Intel i7-3770 CPU, 
laptop 8GB Intel i5-2520M CPU Lenovo T420 (very very slow on performance regression tests)
- all using the Mate Desktop Environment
works as expected on i5-3550 x86_64 with nvidia GTX980 and prop. nvidia driver
Oops, forgot to set flags...
works for me
works for me (x86_64). Default regression test failed (cachedrop).
This update has been pushed to testing.
Works for me. Default regression test passed
i reckon that docking bug hasn't made it upstream yet?
works fine for me on x86_64 i7-5820K.  regression tests  passed.
WFM, Thinkpad X250 docked with laptop panel + one external display over DisplayPort.
WFM, X1 Carbon, Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-5600U, dual monitor, docked, F27 workstation.

Still not booting on docking station with Lenovo X260:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1549042

Waiting for upstream fix...

@markec  after 4.15.x is out in stable updates you DO NOT HELP ANYBODY with your stupid -1 karma because the only thing you now gain is that you hold back new security updates for everybody already running fine on 4.15.x while 4.15.x won't magically disappear - so the only right thing you can do is a 0 karma with a note that you are still affected BUT THIS IS NOT A REGRESSION of 4.15.9 (i personally don't care beause i have already deployed 4.15.9 on all machines F26/F27 including proctuin servers because i use koji and don't depend on the endless waiting for stable-push) but you are doing HARM to everybody else

I'm sorry for inconvenience; I'll use 0 karma from now on, thanks for pointing that out. I'd also appreciate more appropriate language from you in the future as well; my karma wasn't affecting much since there was always enough +1s and my intention wasn't to block other users, but merely to point out defect we're still facing since 4.15.x came out.

@markec  in that case "my karma wasn't affecting much" maybe applies - in other cases such a -1 results in "Bodhi is disabling automatic push to stable due to negative karma" even if there are hundret +1 until the maintainer reviews and decides push by hand
works for me
https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=25702749 fixes it for me ;)
Still paxtest issues, everything is fine otherwise on Lenovo E560
Paxtest failed on Thinkpads x220 and x240 (-1 for kernel regression test case). Other than that everything appears to be working as expected on both systems.
